summary: Email correspondence between Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney Bobbi Sternheim and an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding concerns about Maxwell's conditions of confinement at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) in Brooklyn. The attorney requests Maxwell be moved to an interior cell due to planned water and heat shut-offs, while the prosecutor relays the MDC's assessment that her current isolation cell is appropriate for safety and security.

persons.context: The defendant, housed at MDC under registration number 02879-509. Her attorney is advocating for improved conditions, specifically requesting a move from an isolation cell with exterior walls to an interior cell.

events.title: Judge Nathan Denies Maxwell's Motion on Confinement Conditions
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issued an order denying Ghislaine Maxwell's request for an order concerning the conditions of her confinement at the Metropolitan Detention Center.

events.title: Correspondence Regarding MDC Water and Heat Shut-off
events.description: Email exchange regarding planned NYC Dept. of Design & Construction work that would shut off water and heat to the MDC from 9:00 pm to 5:00 am from November 16 to November 21, 2020.

events.title: Government Letter on Maxwell's Cell Placement
events.description: The Government sent a letter to defense counsel stating the MDC's assessment that Maxwell's current cell is the most appropriate placement for her safety and institutional security.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was housed in an isolation cell with two exterior walls at the Metropolitan Detention Center in November 2020.
Maxwell's defense attorney expressed concern about planned water and heat shut-offs at the MDC and requested her client be moved to an interior cell.
The U.S. Attorney's office relayed the MDC's position that Maxwell's current cell was the most appropriate for her safety and the security of the institution.
Judge Alison J. Nathan had previously denied a motion from Maxwell regarding her conditions of confinement in an August 25, 2020 order.
